Had a lot of fun with this one, does what it says on the tin, literally giving you the opposing sides point of view of the black mesa incident. I really liked how it makes little hints to the previous game and introduced some new creatures and weapons. Also gives a whole new perspective to the previous game in how the military weren't even informed of what was going on before they arrived, showing they were just as clueless as Freeman, love that character arc!

Very nice expansion. Enemies are over all stronger and the puzzles are fewer but still very entertaining.

EPIC LOGIC FAIL, THE GUY IS IN THE ARMY, HE SHOULD HAVE A STRONGER BODY. later on my mouse was fucked up, had to fix that, enemies are also overpowered, two of the same weapons, a knife and a slow heavy wrench... fuck the wrench, the knife is far better and faster, you also get two pistols... why? why make a clone of the  same weapon? the first pistol is already good and the 2nd melee is all you need. gorgon gets the hive hand, you get some zap gun and it too is bullshit, 10 ammo? fuck that. give me 1000, same for the alien grenade. major 10 ammo, thats nothing. way too small for a cool gun, its an insult. you're part of the army and for no reason, theres another faction who actually betray you... WHY? WHERE ON THE SAME SIDE. EPIC LOGIC FAIL. this game sucks

this game is truly ahead of its time (just like any other HL game)

Amazing game. Takes some skill to fight enemies. AI is just good enough to be awesome. Not diluted by story but interesting concept throughout.

Half-Life Opposing Force is one of the three expansions to the original Half-Life game. I found this one quite complete and certainly alluring, to the point where I could personally say that I enjoyed it just as much as the original Half-Life. For this expansion they added many changes to make you really feel immersed into the character of Adrian Shephard, a US Marine that has been sent to Black Mesa to eliminate all the invaders coming from Xen. You often get to play through some levels together with your Marine comrades too, and they help with fire power and health.

Throughout the chapters you find totally new weapons and tools that were not available in the base game. For example, instead of the flashlight you get the night vision mode; instead of the crossbow you get to use a powerful sniper rifle; and instead of the classic crowbar you get a wrench and a knife. As for the new alien weapons, you can use the Displacer Cannon that has a teleport function on the secondary fire click that takes you to different locations inside Xen; you can also obtain a Barnacle‚Äôs tongue to grapple onto certain surfaces; there is a Spore Launcher with Spore fruit as ammo; and you get to use a Shock Roach as a weapon with totally unlimited ammo that auto-regenerates with time. 

The ambiance feels quite achieved, with many dark areas that you must go through using the night vision mode and having no clue as for where you are going or where to look at, which makes for some interesting and even frightening scenarios. The experience overall is not too glitchy, and those glitches that you do find are not game breaking at all. Mostly just getting stuck in trap doors or ramps, from which you will have to noclip out of.

Although not being canon, I think this is a great addition to the saga and gives an interesting insight to the story of Black Mesa from the perspective of the Marines. Totally recommended if you previously enjoyed the original release and want some more content. I do feel that Opposing Force, together with Blue Shift, make this first part of the story feel just a little bit more rounded overall.

First-person-shooter mission packs are usually mediocre: Throw together a few new levels, put in some more guns, add a spider, and you've got a commercial add-on for your aging product. As such, it's appropriate that Gearbox Software's Opposing Force, the official expansion for the genre-redefining Half-Life, in turn sets a new standard of quality for future action-game mission packs.

Opposing Force's story recounts the events of Half-Life, but from the opposing side's perspective as implied by the title. You are Marine Corporal Adrian Shephard. You've been sent to the Black Mesa Research Facility to locate and eliminate Gordon Freeman. As in the original, things immediately go awry, mistakes are made, people die, and your initial plan is replaced with a complicated fight for survival. It's a testament to the success of Half-Life that its story actually warrants retelling. The developers know that while Adrian Shephard has no idea what Freeman is doing, you do, and they pack the game with clues as to where you are in relation to Half-Life's hero. Your path initially converges with Freeman's, then takes some unexpected detours. Many of the original settings and incidents are referred to or revisited from a slightly altered perspective, and it's a ringing endorsement of their effectiveness that to give any of them away would lessen your enjoyment of the game.
